sections.title: DIGITAL ECONOMY AND INNOVATION DEVELOPMENT FUND ACT, 2025
sections.rawText:
An Act to establish the Digital Economy and Innovation Development Fund to provide financial and technical support for digital infrastructure, innovation, skills development, entrepreneurship, and inclusive access to digital services; to ensure sustainable, transparent, and accountable use of resources; and to provide for related matters.

PASSED By Parliament and assented to by the President

sections.title: Meetings of the Board
sections.rawText:
10. (1) The Board shall meet at least once every quarter for the conduct of business at a time and place determined by the Chairperson.

(2)The Chairperson shall preside at meetings of the Board and in the absence of the Chairperson, the members present shall elect one of their number to preside.

(3)The quorum for a meeting of the Board is five members, including at least one representative each from the public and private sectors.

(4) Matters before the Board shall be decided by a majority of the members present and voting and in the event of a tie, the Chairperson shall have a casting vote.

(5) The Board may co-opt any person to attend its meetings but such person shall not have a right to vote.

(6) The Chairperson shall, upon receipt of a written request by not less than onethird of the members of the Board, convene an extraordinary meeting of the Board at a time and place determined by the Chairperson, but not later than fourteen days from the date of the request.

(7) A vacancy in the membership of the Board or any defect in the appointment or qualification of a member does not invalidate proceedings of the Board.

(8) Subject to the provisions of this Act, the Board may determine the procedure for its meetings and the regulation of its own affairs.

executiveSummary:
The **Digital Economy and Innovation Development Fund Act** replaces the Ghana Investment Fund for Electronic Communications (GIFEC) with a significantly expanded mechanism to accelerate Ghana's digital transformation. The Fund operates as an independent legal entity with authority to own property, make contracts, and manage investments, governed by a **Board of Trustees** representing the Ministry, National Communications Authority, Ghana Chamber of Telecommunications, Mobile Network Operators, Parliament, and presidential appointees.

The Fund receives financing from **Parliamentary allocations, mandatory contributions from electronic communication and money service providers, government ICT sector revenue, grants, donations, and investment income**. These resources support six core areas: expanding digital infrastructure in underserved areas, financing digital innovation and startups, developing digital skills programs, creating digital public services (e-health, e-education, e-governance), co-financing projects with private sector partners, and covering operational costs. The Fund can deploy resources through **grants, co-investments, results-based financing, subsidies, or digital vouchers**, with funding decisions guided by transparent prioritization criteria focused on underserved communities and national digital objectives.

**Transparency and accountability mechanisms** include mandatory quarterly public disclosure of funding allocations and project progress via a dedicated website, annual audits by the Auditor-General with reports to Parliament, an Internal Audit Unit providing quarterly oversight, and independent monitoring of subsidized projects. The Board must establish public guidelines for accessing funds, covering eligibility criteria, application procedures, and disbursement processes developed with stakeholder input. The Fund operates with **tax exemption** under the Constitution and Exemptions Act 2022, and unused funds roll over annually for continued use according to approved plans.

The legislation grants the Fund authority to work with the National Communications Authority to **promote spectrum access for rural connectivity** and recommend reduced spectrum fees for operators in underserved areas, as well as propose tariff and interconnection policies supporting affordable rural services. However, the Act creates **new financial obligations for telecommunications and money service providers through mandatory contributions**, and gives the Minister power to issue **binding policy directives** to the Board, which could affect operational independence. The transition from GIFEC transfers all assets, liabilities, and employees to the new Fund with protected employment terms, while repealing relevant sections of the Electronic Communications Act 2008. Success depends on effective Board governance, transparent implementation of disbursement guidelines, genuine multi-stakeholder engagement, and balanced management of the Fund's expanded mandate across infrastructure, innovation, skills development, and digital services.

analysis.analysis:
The **Digital Economy and Innovation Development Fund Act** represents a **major advancement for Ghana's digital innovation ecosystem**, transforming a telecommunications-focused fund into a comprehensive innovation support mechanism. The legislation explicitly mandates support for **digital entrepreneurship, start-ups, innovation hubs, and FinTech initiatives**, backed by diversified funding sources including parliamentary allocations, mandatory contributions from telecom and money service providers, and development partner resources. This creates an institutionalized, sustainable funding pipeline specifically designed to accelerate technology development and entrepreneurial growth—a critical gap in many African innovation ecosystems where access to capital remains a primary barrier.

The **funding modalities and disbursement frameworks** are particularly well-designed for innovation support. The Fund can deploy resources through **outright grants, co-investment partnerships, results-based financing, and digital vouchers**, allowing flexibility to support different innovation stages from early-stage startups to scaling ventures. The provision for **challenge funds and performance-based calls for proposals** creates competitive mechanisms that can drive quality and impact, while **direct disbursement procedures for community-scale or innovation-related initiatives below specified thresholds** reduces bureaucratic barriers for smaller innovators. The transparent, consultative approach to developing guidelines—with public accessibility requirements—ensures that entrepreneurs and innovation organizations can clearly understand and access support opportunities.

Beyond direct funding, the Act creates **ecosystem-enabling conditions** that amplify innovation potential. Support for **digital skills development targeting youth, women, and vulnerable groups** builds the talent pipeline essential for sustainable innovation. Investment in **digital public infrastructure** (e-health, e-education, e-agriculture, e-government platforms) creates market opportunities and use cases for digital innovators to develop solutions. The **spectrum access provisions and rural connectivity support** extend infrastructure to underserved areas, opening new markets and enabling innovations addressing rural challenges. The primary concern is the **ministerial policy directive authority**, which could potentially redirect resources toward political priorities rather than innovation impact, though this risk is somewhat mitigated by transparent governance, public reporting requirements, and multi-stakeholder Board representation. Overall, this legislation provides Ghana's digital innovation sector with dedicated institutional support, flexible funding mechanisms, and ecosystem-building functions that can significantly accelerate technology entrepreneurship and economic transformation.

The Digital Economy and Innovation Development Fund Act creates a **transformative support infrastructure for Ghana's business environment**, particularly for digital economy enterprises and businesses operating in underserved markets. The Fund's mandate to **support digital entrepreneurship, startups, innovation hubs, and FinTech initiatives** through diverse funding mechanisms—including grants, co-investments, results-based financing, and digital vouchers—addresses a critical gap in Ghana's entrepreneurial ecosystem. By providing both financial and non-financial support with **transparent, publicly accessible guidelines developed through stakeholder consultation**, the legislation reduces uncertainty and transaction costs that currently discourage business formation and innovation. The **flexible funding modalities** allow businesses at different development stages to access appropriate capital, from early-stage grants for startups to co-investment partnerships for scaling enterprises.

The Fund's **infrastructure investment mandate** creates substantial indirect benefits for business operations and market expansion. By financing broadband connectivity and digital infrastructure in underserved and unserved areas, the legislation effectively **expands the addressable market** for digital services and reduces operational costs for businesses seeking to serve previously unviable locations. The provisions enabling **collaboration with the National Communications Authority to promote spectrum access** and recommend reduced spectrum fees for rural operators directly lower barriers to entry and expansion costs for telecommunications businesses. Additionally, the Fund's support for **digital skills development programs** addresses workforce constraints that currently limit business growth, while investments in **digital public infrastructure** (e-health, e-education, e-agriculture, e-government platforms) create new business opportunities in platform development, service delivery, and complementary solutions.

The primary concern for business environment stability is the **ministerial power to issue binding policy directives** to the Board, which introduces potential for political interference that could affect predictability and operational independence. This provision creates uncertainty about whether funding priorities and eligibility criteria might shift based on political considerations rather than purely economic or developmental merit. However, this governance risk is substantially mitigated by the **robust transparency and accountability mechanisms**—including quarterly public disclosure of allocations, annual parliamentary audits, and published disbursement guidelines—which create public oversight that constrains arbitrary decision-making. The mandatory contributions from telecommunications and money service providers represent new compliance costs, but these are offset by the ecosystem benefits and potential for reduced spectrum fees in underserved areas. Overall, the legislation creates a **significantly more supportive business environment** for digital economy enterprises while opening new markets and reducing infrastructure constraints across sectors.

keyConcerns.title: Ministerial Override Power Without Safeguards
keyConcerns.description: The Minister can issue **binding policy directives** to the Fund's Board with no defined limits, transparency requirements, or appeal process. The Board "**shall comply**" with these directives on any "**matters of policy**"—a term broad enough to encompass funding priorities, project selection, and resource allocation. This concentrates executive power over a supposedly independent fund managing significant financial resources, undermining the transparent, criteria-based allocation system the Act promises and creating unpredictable conditions for businesses seeking support.
